UK/EUROPE

UK PM May's spokesman claimed that the government will not join a customs union after Brexit, while UK opposition party leader Jeremy Corbyn confirmed the Labour party would seek to join a customs union with the EU. (Newswires)

ECB’s Draghi said inflation is yet to show more convincing signs of sustained upward adjustment and that the Euro area economy is expanding robustly. Furthermore, Draghi also commented that a possible extension of QE has not been discussed. (Newswires)

ECB VP nominee De Guindos said that nobody doubts price stability within the Euro area and that he is reiterating a message of policy continuity in his prepared remarks. (Newswires)


FX

After starting-off on the back-foot in the US pre-market, DXY trades flat heading into APAC trade, with traders taking a cautious approach ahead of Tuesday’s testimony from Fed chair Powell to the House. There wasn’t a specific catalyst for today’s price action, though some FX models point to stronger-than-average USD buying into month-end. At the margin, comments from ECB president Draghi were judged on the dovish side, providing a narrative for a weaker EUR amid the USD strengthening off lows; in early trade, the single currency failed to negotiate 10d SMA and 21d SMA around 1.2355, then slipping beneath the 1.23 handle, before finding support around 1.2280.

With large expiries at the 107 strike, JPY was inching towards the level pre-NY cut, and is consolidating around the figure as we head into APAC trade, shrugging-off the weakness overnight, when BOJ’s Kuroda suggested that there was no need to tweak the central bank’s current easing programme, and no review into its efficacy was required.

GBP is flat, trading around 1.3965 and EURGBP  is slightly above 0.88 (flattish on the day), with the currency happy to look through the pro-EU approach adopted by the leader of the opposition; one bank desk noted that sterling traders are more inclined to trade ‘Brexit facts, rather than Brexit speculation’. With that said, there has been a lot of newsflow regarding the seemingly precarious state of UK politics, with chatter of confidence votes for UK PM May, as well as continual talk of Tory rebels working for a more aggressive Brexit stance.

Commodity FX was tracking commodity prices, while EMFX was mixed. ZAR traders were awaiting details of the new cabinet, and appointments came in line with earlier leaks. BRL and MXN were more rangebound, though the former got a boost after stronger than expected tax receipts in January, while the latter – among the best FX performers YTD – was hit on NAFTA concerns (reports Trump advisor Paul Navarro, a trade hawk, was to get a more prominent role in the administration) as well as weak retail sales data. 

US President Trump claimed US is losing a lot of money to Canada and Mexico. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

CRUDE: WTI futures settle 36 cents higher at $63.91 per barrel; Brent futures settle 19 cents higher at $67.50 per barrel

Oil prices generally traded mixed in early Monday trade, despite bullish comments from the Saudi energy minister over the weekend, who said that the country’s Q1 output would be beneath the levels agreed to in the OPEC+ supply cut deal. Al Falih added that after the current OPEC+ deal expires, OPEC+ would be able to relax output curbs and look to create a permanent ‘framework’ to stabilise markets. Also over the weekend, Libya’s NOC declared force majeure at the 70k BPD El Feel oilfield, though reports today suggested that the Sharara field was unaffected. Crude prices spiked higher in afternoon trade after Genscape was reported to have forecast crude stocks at the Cushing hub were set to draw by 879k in the week, sending crude 50 cents higher to above $64.00. This week, analysts expect to see US crude inventories build by 2.7mln barrels, distillates draw by 0.7ln, gasoline draw by 0.7mln.


GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said North Korea want to talk, as do the US, but only under the right conditions. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

Major equity indices are green, with the EMINI continuing to claw-back losses incurred in the volatility-induced “position adjustment” in early February. In fact, the losses incurred on Monday 5 February (the second day of the sell-off) have now been pared, with the 2840 level now in focus (highs from Friday 2/Feb, the day the sell-off began in earnest). The backdrop for Monday’s gains were inspired by falling Treasury yields, which were said to have soothed investors’ fears about sharp rate rises. Tech shares continued to be in vogue (best performing sector in 2018 YTD), after Qualcomm urged Broadcom to negotiate a price for a deal. On the other end of the scale, the defensive utilities sector lagged. The VIX continues to ease-back, now trading in the low-16s. SPX +1.18% at 2780, DJI +1.57%, NDX +1.3% at 6989.

Ahead of Fed chair Powell’s testimony to the House on Tuesday, Treasury yields were lower by between 1bps to 2bps across the curve, with 10-year yields falling to 2.85%. Most major curve spreads were little changed, though the 5s30s curve was wider by 1.3bps at settlement. Powell is expected to stick to the script, though some are wondering how he will avoid sounding too hawkish. T-Note futures settled 3 ticks higher at 120-26+.

US MARKET WRAP: Markets tread water ahead of Powell testimony
content:
CENTRAL BANK SPEAK: ECB’s Draghi, de Guindos, Coeure; Fed’s Quarles, Bullard

ECB’s Draghi revealed little by way of new information in his testimony to lawmakers in Brussels. However, some analysts judged his comments to be on the dovish side, after the ECB president stated that there was uncertainty regarding the measurement of slack, saying that the true amount may in fact be larger than current estimates. Elsewhere, Draghi reiterated the ECB’s current forward guidance, that inflation is yet to show signs of a sustainable rise towards target. ECB vice president nominee de Guindos was also in front of lawmakers today, and strictly toed the line in terms of current ECB guidance, giving traders little indication of where he lies on the hawk-dove scale. De Guindos drove-home a message of continuity, noting that rates will begin to rise after the conclusion of bond-buying (in line with ECB guidance). The nominee talked-up the success that the ECB had made in re-anchoring inflation expectations, and said that, over time, ECB policy will converge to the Fed. ECB’s Coeure, meanwhile, said over the weekend that the ECB can slow bond purchases, as long as it gives a clear guidance on the path of interest rates.

Ahead of tomorrow’s testimony by Fed chair Powell to the House Financial Services committee, Fed’s Quarles (voter) – in his first monetary policy speech – said it would be appropriate for gradual rate hikes. He sees inflation moving back towards target in the medium term, though said it remains to be seen whether higher growth will spur inflation. Quarles was optimistic on growth, suggesting that there a\re some upside risks. Fed’s Bullard (non-voter) once again stated his familiar concerns about how Fed rate hikes could make the central bank’s policy restrictive, and how he believes that rate guidance should outline a relatively flat path of hikes. He did concede, however, that inflation expectations had edged upwards, and elsewhere said he was unconcerned by recent market volatility.

There were no notable comments on monetary policy from BOE Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe.

PREVIEW: New Fed Chair Powell to deliver semi-annual testimony to Congress
content:
WHEN

Text of Testimony to be released on Tuesday 27th February 2018 at 1330GMT/0830EST

Testimony before the House Financial Services Committee on Tuesday 27th February at 1500GMT/1000EST

Testimony before the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday 1st March at 1500GMT/1000EST

PREVIEW

Fed Chair Powell will deliver his first monetary policy testimony to Congress, beginning on Tuesday in front of the House Financial Services Committee and continuing on Thursday in front of the Senate Banking Committee.

Powell is widely expected to follow a similar path to Janet Yellen and reiterate that further gradual increases in the Fed Funds Rate (FFR) are warranted. With a March rate hike appearing to be a forgone conclusion, it would take a huge dovish u-turn from Powell for the Fed to delay hiking next month.

Markets will instead be looking at the comments for any clues on whether four 25bps rate hikes in 2018 are likely. Back in his testimony ahead of getting confirmed as Fed Chair, Powell said that risks to the economy appeared to be balanced.

“The median rate projection of the FOMC last December called for three 25bps rate hikes in 2018, and we expect Powell’s comments to be supportive of this outlook,” writes HSBC.

Nevertheless, Powell would most likely prefer to keep the option of a fourth hike in 2018 open without so much as confirming it. “A clear majority of the FOMC, including its new Chairman, will want the optionality on the table of a potential, perhaps even probable, fourth rate hike this year,” writes SGH Macro Advisers. “But our sense is that Powell and most of his Committee colleagues will not want to signal the fourth rate move as a given in either the testimony or, we suspect, the March meeting.”

On inflation, the Fed had previously categorised inflation weakness as “transitory,” (in his November confirmation hearing, Powell himself alluded to uncertainty regarding the path of inflation). However, the recent CPI data and average hourly earnings data both point to an acceleration in price pressures. The focus is on how Powell frames the recent firming. UBS believes Powell will likely project increased confidence that inflation will rise to target this year.

FED POLICY FRAMEWORK

A number of policymakers, including Rosengren and Mester, have recently spoken about how they’d like a review of the Fed’s policy framework. HSBC speculate that the topic could come up in the Q&A and markets will be looking for whether Powell would be open to reviewing the policy framework and his thoughts on alternatives to the current 2% inflation target, whether that be price-level targeting or a target-range for inflation.

MARKET VOLATILITY

The recent market volatility has been attributed to inflationary pressures forcing traders to reprice their expectations of the Fed hiking cycle. After the FOMC’s experience of the ‘taper tantrum’ in 2013, it will be cautious about managing market expectations.

At his swearing-in ceremony Powell alluded to the recent market volatility, stating that the Fed will “remain alert” to any financial stability risks presented by market gyrations. “He will labor to avoid even a whiff of baby-sitting a wobbly stock market with a ‘Powell put’ readiness to intervene,” SGH writes. “But he will be equally forceful in affirming the Fed will not rush to raise rates against what it believes will be a rising but hardly accelerationist inflation.”

subject: FX Daily Wrap: DXY bounces firmly off 89.500 low
content: Some early month end buying and option expiry interest appears to have revived the flagging Dollar’s fortunes with the Index rebounding to almost 90.000 and Usd/Jpy retesting 107.00 from sub-106.50 lows earlier in the session. 2.2 bn ran off at the NY cut between the figure and 107.05, while Cable had Gbp2 bn at the 1.4000 strike, but in truth was well below some time before 15.00GMT. Sterling could have been undermined by the latest Brexit-related UK political instability, as opposition Labour leader Corbyn laid out his party’s blueprint for life outside the EU, including plans to remain in the customs union, which a spox for PM May denounced. Gbp/Usd hit 1.3950 lows and Eur/Gbp rebounded above 0.8800, while Eur/Usd dipped below 1.2300 having failed to convincingly build on gains through its 1.2346 DMA and 1.2350, but derived some underlying support from ECB President Draghi (growth more robust, and inflation to rise gradually, albeit still subdued). Usd/Cad extended to the upside and tested 1.2700 (ahead of 1.2705 resistance) on persistent NAFTA uncertainty, with Usd/Mxn also firmer (within a 18.5470-18.6900 range) after Mexico’s President ditched plans to visit his US counterpart after a strained phone conversation about the controversial wall. Nzd/Usd just held above 0.7300 as Aud/Usd retreated a bit further from near 0.7900 highs towards 0.7830 and the Aud/Nzd cross slipped back to circa 1.0700 from 1.0770.

ECB’s Draghi says inflation is yet to show more convincing signs of sustained upward adjustment, Euro area economy is expanding robustly
content:
- Draghi says "the evolution of inflation remains crucially conditional on an ample degree of monetary stimulus provided by the full set of our monetary policy measures: our net asset purchases, the sizeable stock of acquired assets and the forthcoming reinvestments, and our forward guidance on policy interest rates"
- On the EUR exchange rate, Draghi says "we anticipate that headline inflation will resume its gradual upward adjustment, supported by our monetary policy measures. At the same time, uncertainties continue to prevail. In particular, the recent volatility in financial markets, notably also in the exchange rate, deserves close monitoring with regard to its possible implications for the medium-term outlook for price stability"

content:
1. 26th February 2018

    EARNINGS

    Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) – Q4 Operating EPS USD 3338 vs Exp. USD 2622.23, FY17 Operating EPS USD 14457 vs Exp. USD 9384.5. Following the Tax reform, the co.  received an immediate USD 29bln windfall and noted there is a large amount of cash which is hopefully going to be deployed but is struggling to find a good business at the right price. (Newswires)

    Dean Foods (DF) Q4 Adj. EPS USD 0.25 vs Exp. USD 0.26, revenue USD 1.93bln vs Exp. USD 1.96bln. Forecasts Fy18 EPS between USD 0.55 – 0.80 vs Exp. USD 0.86. (Newswires)

    Kosmos (KOS) Q4 Adj. Loss Per Share USD 0.10 vs Exp. Loss per share USD 0.11, revenue USD 187.1mln vs Exp. USD 168.31mln. (Newswires)

  2. DJIA

    Apple (AAPL) – The tech giant is to store encryption keys for accounts based in China. Apple are also working on a branded over ear wireless headphones. Further for the co., Samsung have unveiled their latest smartphone which is to compete with Apple’s iPhone X. Also, Berkshire Hathaway said Apple was its most bought stock in 2017. (WSJ / Newswires)

    Boeing Co (BA) – The jet manufacturing giant is to build a 51% stake in a joint company negotiated with aircraft maker Embraer (ERJ). (O Globo)

    Cisco (CSCO) – The network giant announced it had launched a new 5G Now portfolio. Separately, it is also working with TIM to increase IT security of Italian companies. (Newswires)

    General Electric (GE) – The tech giant may face action from the Department of Justice which claims one of its unit, GE Capital, broke laws in connection with subprime mortgages. Separately, the co. is to restate earnings for 2016 & 2017 and it announced three new board members for 2018. Separately, Berkshire Hathaway CEO Warren Buffett says he has not purchased any shares in GE and notes he would not buy GE Healthcare to tie into the healthcare initiative but says he may be interested in smaller units of the co. if they go up for sale. (Newswires)

    Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) – The pharmaceutical giant’s sterilisation unit has gathered bids from Cantel Medical (CMD) and Medtronic (MDT), joining Carlyle (CG) KKR (KKR), and 3M (MMM). The unit is expected to be sold for roughly USD 2bln. (Newswires)

  3. S&P500

    Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) – CEO Warren Buffett said he is more likely to repurchase stock than to offer dividends to use excess cash. (Newswires)

    Kraft Heinz (KHC) – Warren Buffett is to retire from the co. board as it nears the end of his term at the co. However, he said leaving the board does not indicate declining interest. (Newswires)

    Wells Fargo (WFC) – Warren Buffett says he has confidence in the banks CEO Sloan and says it will get through the sanctions from the Fed. (Newswires)

    Aetna (AET) / CVS Health (CVS) – Aetna have noted the deal between the two is part of a long-term solution to move towards a value-based system which rewards pharmaceutical manufacturers for health care outcomes. (Newswires)

    Qorvo (QRVO) – The co. is to supply Microsoft (MSFT) with a full suite of RF Fusion models for its Surface Pro. (Newswires)

    Network Names (CSCO, T, QCOM) – Of note, Nokia (NOK) and Vodafone Italy (VOD) are started a 5G trial in Milan. (Newswires)

    Eli Lilly (LLY) – The co.’s Trulicity significantly improved blood sugar control in type 2 diabetes. (Newswires)

    US Banks – Lawmakers under the Trump Administration are expected to raise the threshold for systematically important banks to USD 250bln, opening M&A opportunities for medium sized banks. (Newswires)

    Medtronic (MDT) – The medical device co. received FDA approval for a new arm indication on the Guardian Sensor 3. (Newswires)

    Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) / Amazon (AMZN) / JP Morgan (JPM) – Warren Buffett has said the healthcare tie up between the three should have a ‘top notch’ CEO within a year. (Newswires)

    Air Names (DAL, AAL, LUV, UAL, ALK) – Warren Buffett says he will not rule out owning an entire airline. (Newswires)

    United Parcel Service Inc (UPS) – The co. claimed USD 1.742bln in damages from the EU anti-trust authority after its bid for TNT was halted five years ago. (Newswires)

    Gun Names (AOBC, RGR) – Avis Budget (CAR), Delta (DAL) and United Airlines (UAL) are among latest companies to eliminate discounts for the NRA. (Newswires)

  4. NASDAQ 100

    Allergan (AGN) / Mylan (MYL) – Mylan said the Patent Trial and Appeal Board has denied the St Regis Mohawk Tribes motion to terminate Mylan’s patent challenge related to Allergan’s Restasis. (Newswires)

    Amazon (AMZN) – Warren Buffett does not own Amazon, but he would not bet against it. (Newswires)

    Baidu (BIDU) – Alibaba (BABA) are to purchase the remainder of Ele.me from the co. as well as other investors, in May last year it was valued at USD 5.5-6bln. (Newswires)

    Mylan (MYL) – Wendy Cameron, a non-executive director is to retire from the board. (Newswires)

    Qualcomm (QCOM) – Qualcomm Tech, a co. subsidiary announced its Snapdragon is powering Samsung’s latest smart phone. (Newswires)

    Qualcomm (QCOM) / Broadcom (AVGO) – Qualcomm proposed further talks with Broadcom over the transaction price and terms of deal, encouraging the co. to enter a mutual due diligence. (Newswires)

  5. OTHER NEWS

    Amdocs (DOX) – The co. announced a strategic collaboration with Amazon’s (AMZN) Web Services. (Newswires)

    Chemed (CHE) – Gabelli have reported a 4.28% stake into the co. (Newswires)

    CommScope (COMM) – The co. is collaborating with Nokia to develop a Multiple Input/Multiple Output integrated antenna. (Newswires)

    Energy Transfer Partners (ETP) – Works were partially halted at the oil co.’s Bayou Bridge crude pipeline as a federal authority withdrew a permit last Friday after a number of protests were held by local environmental groups. (Newswires)

    Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) – The automaker is planning to eliminate all diesel passenger vehicles from its automobile line-up by 2022. (FT)

    GTT Communication (GTT) – The co. is to acquire Interoute for approximately USD 1.9bln. (Newswires)

    Madison Square Garden (MSG) – Silver Lake increased its stake in the co. to 6.3% from 4.8%. (Newswires)

    Meredith (MDP) – The co. is to sell Time Inc. (TIME) UK to Epiris. (Newswires)

    Spectrum Brands (SPB) / HRG Group (HRG) – The two are to combine in a transaction valued at USD 10bln. (Newswires)

    Steel Names (X, AKS) – US President Trump said to want a 24% global tariff on steel imports. (Newswires)

    Teva (TEVA) – The investment into the pharmaceutical co. was not Warren Buffett’s Decision. (Newswires)

content: Short Sterling futures have calmed down somewhat as the selling seen earlier abates and the strip sits nearer the top of the ranges traded so far, albeit still 1 to 2 ticks adrift. Meanwhile, a flurry of option trades has seen largely 2-way interest with Mar18 99.25 puts sold and 99.375 calls bought, but 99.125 puts also bought vs Jun18 99.00 as a diagonal calendar spread. The Jun18 99.125/99.25/99.375 call butterfly has been bought and the Dec 99.125/99.00/98.875 put ladder sold, while in the Apr mid curve expiry the 98.75/98.625/98.50 put butterfly was purchased in bigger size.

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: A positive start to the week for European equities (Eurostoxx 50 +0.5%), which have taken the impetus from Asian equities overnight.
content:
26th February 2018

  • A positive start to the week for European equities (Eurostoxx 50 +0.5%), which have taken the impetus from Asian equities overnight.
  • The DXY is back below 90.000 yet again, and on broad losses for the Greenback vs G10 peers bar the Loonie (Usd/Cad holding above 1.2600 towards the middle of a 1.2615-60 range)
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US New Home Sales and a slew of speakers from the ECB, BoE and Fed

ASIA

Asian stock markets began the week on the front-foot as the region took impetus from last Friday’s late rally on Wall St and with energy names underpinned by recent strength in crude prices. ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) were both higher in which earnings fuelled the biggest gainers in Australia, while Japanese exporters weathered a firmer JPY and led the region’s advances. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) were in the green with Geely Auto the outperformer after reports its parent amassed a near 10% stake in Daimler, although Chinese property names were less fortunate with the Shanghai Comp. Property Index slumping 3% in early trade after the latest House data showed efforts to curb the sector were gaining fruition. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher amid mild gains in USTs, while the Japanese yield curve was mixed as longer-dated bonds underperforming after the BoJ kept its operations concentrated in the belly.

 

PBoC injected CNY 100bln via 7-day, CNY 30bln via 28-day and CNY 20bln via 63-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3378 (Prev. 6.3482)

Chinese House Prices (Jan) 5.0% (Prev. 5.3%). (Newswires)

Chinese Property Prices rose M/M in 52 out of 70 cities (Prev. 57) and rose Y/Y in 59 out of 70 cities (Prev. 61).

Chinese President Xi Jinping’s policy advisor Liu He is said to emerge as the front runner to head the PBoC when current Governor Zhou retires. (Newswires)

China’s Communist Party is said to propose to drop limits on presidential terms which would allow President Xi Jinping to remain as the nation’s president indefinitely. (Newswires)

BoJ Governor Kuroda reiterated that the BoJ will continue with powerful monetary easing to achieve the price target. Furthermore, Kuroda also commented that Japan's economy needs persistent monetary easing and that there is currently no plan for a new comprehensive assessment. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

The UK’s Office for Budget Responsibility is set for an embarrassing U-turn as it prepares to dramatically hike forecasts for UK growth just months after they were suddenly downgraded. (Telegraph)

Three cabinet ministers warned PM May during private talks on Brexit at her Chequers retreat last week that her government could collapse this year. According to reports, senior ministers said there are discussions about whether the prime minister should turn the vote into a confidence issue, threatening a general election if Tory MPs vote with the opposition. (Sunday Times)

UK opposition leader Corbyn is set to confirm today that the Labour Party will oppose PM May’s plans to take Britain out of the customs union with the EU. (FT)

EU is said to stand firm over Northern Ireland border and that the Brexit treaty text is to not include crucial compromise language secured by UK PM May. (FT)

UK Finance Mortgage Apps (Jan) 40.1k vs. Exp. 37.2k (Prev. 36.115k)

CENTRAL BANKS

BoE's Ramsden said there seems to be more impetus on wages and that they will keep a close eye on what happens through the early part of this year to see if that forecast [in a Bank survey] of wage growth picking up to 3% is realised. Ramsden also commented that certainly relative to where he was, he now sees the case for rates rising somewhat sooner rather than somewhat later. (Sunday Times) Note: Ramsden was one of the two dissenters on the MPC when the BoE decided to hike rates in November 2017, citing concerns over wage growth prospects as a reason to refrain from lifting rates.

 

EQUITIES

A positive start to the week for European equities (Eurostoxx 50 +0.5%), which have taken the impetus from Asian equities overnight. The gains this morning have been largely broad-based across all major sectors, while material names outperform with miners tracking the moves higher in commodity prices which have been buoyed by the softer USD. Moves higher in the FTSE 100 have been capped by the GBP strength which had been given a boost by surprisingly hawkish comments from BoE’s Ramsden, while election risks have contained the upside in the FTSE MIB. In stock specific news, the troubled lender, Profident Financial are trading with losses of over 13% ahead of their earnings tomorrow.

FX

The DXY is back below 90.000 yet again, and on broad losses for the Greenback vs G10 peers bar the Loonie (Usd/Cad holding above 1.2600 towards the middle of a 1.2615-60 range). Some market observers say the renewed bout of weakness reflects a pull-back in yields, but that correlation remains tenuous given the fact that the Dollar did not rally in tandem with 10 year cash hitting peaks around 2.95% (circa 10 basis points above current levels) at the heights last week, or at least not to the same degree. Hence, it is concerns about the US fiscal situation and rising deficits that are still weighing on sentiment alongside some political angst as President Trump continues to push protectionist policies. Even month end demand has not given the Usd much of a boost, as yet anyway, with Eur/Usd firmly back above 1.2300 and testing 1.2346 DMA resistance despite bearish cross flow via Eur/Jpy that has tested near term chart support just ahead of 131.00. Cable has breached its 21 DMA and 1.4050 amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty, and Usd/Jpy has retreated to 106.50 from 107.00+. The Greenback may derive some support from big option expiries, with circa 2 bn in both Cable and Usd/Jpy at 1.4000 and 107.00-05 respectively.   

FIXED INCOME

The 10 year German benchmark saw an abrupt downturn and reversal broadly on the EU equity cash opening bells as positive indications via stock futures materialised. Bunds had already pared some losses, but were holding around parity before sliding to a 159.25 low (-23 ticks vs +18 ticks at best), and perhaps also declining in sympathy with Gilts that gapped down straightaway to 121.71 (-24 ticks) amidst hawkish BoE and upbeat/bullish economic growth impulses. However, the main UK bond subsequently regained some composure to trade just 3 ticks above last Friday’s settlement level before fading, and it appears to be a mixture of chart gap-filling, early month end and ongoing positioning for the March expiry and roll into June that has prompted choppy price moves since the Liffe and Eurex opens. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are somewhat side-lined, but maintaining a flatter bias in quiet overnight trade.

COMMODITIES

In the commodities complex, WTI and Brent crude futures pulled off best levels with WTI running into resistance around USD 64 to move back down to the mid-USD 63s. Over the weekend, Saudi Energy Miniset Al Falih stated that he expects production cuts to ease next year (Current OPEC/ Non-OPEC production cut due to expire at year-end). Elsewhere, Barclays sees a significant risk of a market correction in H2 as a result of builds in inventories. 

 

Barclays says 2018 crude forecast of USD 60bbl for Brent and USD 55bbl for WTI is unchanged

-Barclays expects backwardation in WTI and Brent Futures curves to subside later this year

-Barclays also sees a significant risk of market correction in H2 2018 due to builds in inventories

 

Libya's El Sharara oil field, which accounts for 308,000 bpd, is not affected by closure of el feel field-engineer. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korean General Kim Yong Chol says the door is open for talks with US, according to Yonhap. (Newswires)

subject: Rio Tinto (RIO LN) has struck a deal to offload its last aluminium smelters in Europe
Fixed Income: Bunds retreat swiftly, Gilts gap down from the off
content: The 10 year German benchmark saw an abrupt downturn and reversal broadly on the EU equity cash opening bells as positive indications via stock futures materialised. Bunds had already pared some losses, but were holding around parity before sliding to a 159.34 low (-14 ticks vs +18 ticks at best), and perhaps also declining in sympathy with Gilts that gapped down straightaway to 121.71 (-24 ticks) amidst hawkish BoE and upbeat/bullish economic growth impulses. However, the main UK bond subsequently regained some composure to trade just 3 ticks above last Friday’s settlement level before fading, and it appears to be a mixture of chart gap-filling, early month end and ongoing positioning for the March expiry and roll into June that has prompted choppy price moves since the Liffe and Eurex opens. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are somewhat side-lined, but maintaining a flatter bias in quiet overnight trade.

Short Sterling futures hit after steady start
content: The UK STIR strip has succumbed to some heavy selling pressure after returning to Liffe flat to just 1 tick adrift, with losses extended to as much as 5 ticks at one stage following more hawkish comments from BoE’s Ramsden over the weekend and reports that the OBR may have to sharply upgrade its GDP forecasts based on better than expected services growth in Q4, according to the CBI. Gilts may also underperform on the same rationale and kick-off Monday’s session on the back foot despite firmer Bunds and US Treasuries (albeit former after erasing all gains to trade flat at 159.48 a short while ago). Ahead, mortgage data on the domestic agenda and then another BoE speech after hours as Cunliffe orates.

subject: Bunds: fixed recovery continues ahead of month end
content: A firmer Eurex open in line with the tone in US Treasuries as bonds retrace further from recent lows/multi-year highs in cash yield terms. No real catalyst behind the latest moves that appear more technical and profit-related as the US 10 year yield appears to have rejected a test of 3%, while some are also pointing to early month end positioning as the index extensions for USTs are above average for February. From a macro perspective, strong US inflation/wage and other data may have largely run its course in terms of near term Fed policy implications and speakers have not inferred any material or confirmed change from the central scenario of 3 hikes this year. For the core German bond future perhaps some underlying safe-haven demand ahead of Italy’s election and the SPD coalition vote both falling on March 4th, but Bunds are drifting back in the run up to the EU bourse opens within a 159.49-66 range vs last Friday’s 159.48 close.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

26th February 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stock markets began the week on the front-foot as the region took impetus from last Friday’s late rally on Wall St and with energy names underpinned by recent strength in crude prices. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.3%) were both higher in which earnings fuelled the biggest gainers in Australia, while Japanese exporters weathered a firmer JPY and led the region’s advances. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) were in the green with Geely Auto the outperformer after reports its parent amassed a near 10% stake in Daimler, although Chinese property names were less fortunate with the Shanghai Comp. Property Index slumping 3% in early trade after the latest House data showed efforts to curb the sector were gaining fruition.

Directors of the GBP 112bln group are expected to hold a vote in the next few weeks to decide whether to move its headquarters to Rotterdam — scrapping its joint head office in London. (Sunday Times)

EQUITIES: NDX +2% at 6897, SPX +1.61% at 2747, DJI +1.4% at 25311

Top sectors: Utilities +2.7%, Energy +2.2%, IT +2.2%

Bottom sectors: +0.8%, Telecom +0.8%, Consumer Staples +1%

The ES H8 contract was again in the 2700 to 2730 battleground (50d MA around 2730 in focus), remaining in positive territory throughout the course of the session, with utilities and staples doing a lot of the heavy lifting (all sectors were green). Late in the day, however, ES managed to find some impetus in quiet trade, rising out of that range towards session highs – with some chatter of a mini short squeeze – shaking-off the lethargy seen in recent afternoon trade. There wasn’t a specific narrative behind Friday’s equity gains, with many news outlets attributing the gains to Fed-related headlines, though that seems to be trying fit a narrative around the price action, rather than actually explaining the price action. Perhaps a more convincing explanation was the fall in US yields providing support (some models signal month-end Treasury buying). In stock specific news, HPE jumped after reporting earnings on Thursday, GIS was the laggard after announcing an $8bln deal to buy BUFF; in late trade, news that JWN family members were reportedly near finalising an offer to take the company private added a positive catalyst to equity trading. While stock trading has been choppy this week, ES finishes in the green (very slightly – and last week’s highs haven’t been meaningfully tested), though the range has been the narrowest in around six weeks.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stock markets began the week on the front-foot as the region took impetus from last Friday’s late rally on Wall St
content:
• Asian stock markets began the week on the front-foot as the region took impetus from last Friday’s late rally on Wall St
  • In FX markets, USD weakness persisted as yields declined overnight. EUR/USD and GBP/USD reclaim 1.2300 and 1.4000
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US New Home Sales and a slew of speakers from the ECB, BoE and Fed

ASIA

Asian stock markets began the week on the front-foot as the region took impetus from last Friday’s late rally on Wall St and with energy names underpinned by recent strength in crude prices. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.3%) were both higher in which earnings fuelled the biggest gainers in Australia, while Japanese exporters weathered a firmer JPY and led the region’s advances. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) were in the green with Geely Auto the outperformer after reports its parent amassed a near 10% stake in Daimler, although Chinese property names were less fortunate with the Shanghai Comp. Property Index slumping 3% in early trade after the latest House data showed efforts to curb the sector were gaining fruition. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher amid mild gains in USTs, while the Japanese yield curve was mixed as longer-dated bonds underperforming after the BoJ kept its operations concentrated in the belly.

PBoC injected CNY 100bln via 7-day, CNY 30bln via 28-day and CNY 20bln via 63-day reverse repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3378 (Prev. 6.3482)

Chinese House Prices (Jan) 5.0% (Prev. 5.3%). (Newswires)
Chinese Property Prices rose M/M in 52 out of 70 cities (Prev. 57) and rose Y/Y in 59 out of 70 cities (Prev. 61).

Chinese President Xi Jinping’s policy advisor Liu He is said to emerge as the front runner to head the PBoC when current Governor Zhou retires. (Newswires)

China’s Communist Party is said to propose to drop limits on presidential terms which would allow President Xi Jinping to remain as the nation’s president indefinitely. (Newswires)

BoJ Governor Kuroda reiterated that the BoJ will continue with powerful monetary easing to achieve the price target. Furthermore, Kuroda also commented that Japan's economy needs persistent monetary easing and that there is currently no plan for a new comprehensive assessment. (Newswires)

UK/EU

BoE's Ramsden said there seems to be more impetus on wages and that they will keep a close eye on what happens through the early part of this year to see if that forecast [in a Bank survey] of wage growth picking up to 3% is realised. Ramsden also commented that certainly relative to where he was, he now sees the case for rates rising somewhat sooner rather than somewhat later. (Sunday Times) Note: Ramsden was one of the two dissenters on the MPC when the BoE decided to hike rates in November 2017, citing concerns over wage growth prospects as a reason to refrain from lifting rates.

The UK’s Office for Budget Responsibility is set for an embarrassing U-turn as it prepares to dramatically hike forecasts for UK growth just months after they were suddenly downgraded. (Telegraph)

Three cabinet ministers warned PM May during private talks on Brexit at her Chequers retreat last week that her government could collapse this year. According to reports, senior ministers said there are discussions about whether the prime minister should turn the vote into a confidence issue, threatening a general election if Tory MPs vote with the opposition. (Sunday Times)

UK PM May is said to propose blurring her Brexit redline on the European Court of Justice and is said to mull signing up to EU regulators for key industries. (Newswires)

UK opposition leader Corbyn is set to confirm today that the Labour Party will oppose PM May’s plans to take Britain out of the customs union with the EU. (FT)

EU is said to stand firm over Northern Ireland border and that the Brexit treaty text is to not include crucial compromise language secured by UK PM May. (FT)

EU’s Tusk said we have guidelines ready to start negotiations about future relations after Brexit whether the UK is ready with its vision or not, while he added that he is afraid the UK position at the moment is based on pure illusion. (Newswires)

S&P raised Russia Ratings to BBB- from BB+; Outlook revised to Stable and affirmed Turkey at 'BB'; Outlook Negative. (Newswires) Fitch affirmed Russia at 'BBB-'; Outlook Positive and affirmed Slovenia at A-; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, USD weakness persisted as yields declined overnight and with participants tentative ahead of Fed Chair Powell’s testimony to Congress this week. As such, the greenback lost ground against its major counterparts in which EUR/USD and GBP/USD reclaimed the 1.2300 and 1.4000 handles respectively. Elsewhere, NZD/USD also tripped through stops on a break above the 0.7300 level, while reiterations from Governor Kuroda failed to alleviate the pressure on USD/JPY.

COMMODITIES

Commodities gained overnight on the back of a weaker greenback in which WTI crude futures extended on its highest level in over 2 weeks and approached the USD 64/bbl level. Elsewhere, precious metals outperformed with gold up as much as USD 10/oz during intraday trade due to the softer USD, with focus shifting to Fed’s Powell inaugural semi-annual testimony.

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (16 Feb) 978 (Prev. 975). (Newswires)

Saudi Oil Minister Al Falih said that Saudi Arabia expects oil cuts to ease next year, which is anticipated to not hurt the market. (Newswires)

US President Trump is said to want a 24% global tariff on steel imports. (Newswires)

South Africa's National Union of Mineworkers on Sunday said that Pan African Resources is to reduce 1,722 workers at its Evander Gold Mine. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korean senior officials said on Sunday their government was open to talks with the US, while the US responded that any talks with North Korea must lead to an end to its nuclear program. (Newswires)


US

Month-end flows were seen supporting the Treasury Complex, and yields were lower across the curve. Some pointed out that index extensions this month are large, which may be contributing to Treasury buying. Some were also attributing Treasury gains to jittery stock markets, although that narrative is challenged by the equity price action, which has hardly screamed ‘panic’. The complex will likely take its next cue from Fed chair Powell’s testimony to Congress next week; fixed income traders will be looking for clues as to whether the Fed will raise its assessment of long-term rates, which could help the curve steepen. US T-Note futures settle 10 ticks higher at 120-23+.

Fed’s Williams (Voter, Neutral) stated to keep the expansion going we must not let the economy overheat, while he added that the labour market looks very strong and is seeing a pick-up in wage growth. (Newswires)

Fed's Mester (Voter, Hawk) said the economic expansion is in place, labour markets are strong and sees inflation rising to 2%. Furthermore, Mester added it may be time to review the Fed's monetary policy framework. (Newswires)
